newsitem.title: USA: COMEX copper ends at seven week lows.
newsitem.headline: COMEX copper ends at seven week lows.

text.p: COMEX copper futures fell sharply to end at seven week lows Wednesday, led down by LME copper which also fell to seven week lows.

"There's no news behind it, just supply overwhelming demand and a break of key support around 88 cents on decent volume in December copper which caught many people asleep," Triland USA trader Brent Tolen said.
COMEX December fell 2.85 cents to 87.15 a lb after hitting a session low at 87.00, its lowest level since July 22.
The December/March backwardation narrowed further to 1.10 cents, from 1.50 cents at Tuesday's close.
The wide backwardation of recent weeks looks to have attracted copper supplies to exchange inventories recently, easing the prompt tightness, analysts said.
COMEX copper warehouse stocks have risen steadily to over 20,000 short tons from less than 5,000 short tons in June.

In the past few days both COMEX and LME copper prices had been consolidating near the bottom of the range of the past two months, after swinging in a wide range last week, partly on options related trade as short positions, established during the Sumitomo affair earlier this year, were unwound.
"Prices are susceptible to a technical selloff," one analyst said.
"But a number of U.S. producers continue to buy copper in the spot market to meet sales commitments which could moderate the extent of any price decline."
